title: The Asian Origins of Global Capitalism: European Factories in the Indian Ocean, 1500-1800
descriptions:
The grant proposal, titled "The Asian Origins of Global Capitalism: European Factories in the Indian Ocean, 1500-1800", aims to explore the origins of modern industrial capitalism by focusing on the economic activities in Asian ports controlled by European East India companies during the time period of 1500-1800. The project will investigate the interactive roles of European and local merchants in these imperial trading centers, mapping the intercontinental movement of goods, people, and information to recast the narrative of global economic change and capitalism.

Key concepts to be explored include factories, factors, intercontinental trade, spatial theory of capitalist development, New History of Capitalism, and decolonization of the history of capitalism. The methodology involves the integration of large archival repositories and collaborations globally, with a project duration of 5 years.

The proposed research will investigate over 150 factories as the foundation for a new spatial theory of capitalist development, shedding light on the economic dynamism and global trade that shaped the early stages of modern capitalism. By uncovering the overlooked role of Asian ports in the development of global capitalism, this project seeks to contribute a new perspective to the understanding of economic history and its implications for contemporary global economies.
